newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: INTERVIEW - DB Group sees trend to quality.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - DB Group sees trend to quality.

text.p: DB Group Ltd Managing Director Erik Korthals Altes said the answer to New Zealand's declining beer and wine consumption was in positioning the company to take advantage of a clearly defined trend toward quality.
Korthals Altes said in an interview the net decline was created by a "massive" change in consumption patterns.

"Beer, instead of being something as a means to get drunk and to show your machismo among your friends, is becoming more a part of social interaction and enjoying yourself, a social lubricant," he said.
"We have seen a massive shift to glass, we see a shift away from tap beer. The net effect is less consumption," he said.
DB had seen the same thing happen with its Corbans wine business, where people were increasingly trading up from casks to bottles.
Korthals Altes said DB, after suffering a decline in its share of the domestic beer market since 1990, had finally turned the corner.

"The interesting thing is that part of the recovery of our market share came from the higher end of the market, where discounting is not playing a role, whereas some of our competitors are trying to reverse the market trend by lowering prices. That's not working."
DB Group is 59.8 percent owned by Asia Pacific Breweries Ltd, a venture between Heineken NV and Fraser and Neave Ltd.
Korthals Altes said locally-brewed Heineken, while not a big brand in New Zealand, had opened doors for the DB stable. Like Heineken, DB Export was now seen as a "must-stock" brand.
"Heineken is at the top of the pyramid. Okay, the volume is not fantastic, but anybody who wants to trade up will be caught by Heineken and that is working."
To Korthals Altes, whose backround is in marketing with the Dutch brewer, discounting is a dirty word. Heineken, which sells locally at NZ$19.95 a dozen, would never be discounted, he said.
"It seems that there is only one solution in New Zealand minds to compensate for volume loss and that is lower prices.
"We are no longer short-term reactive. We are proactive.
"We set our own course. We take in signals from the market, review them and decide whether we will react at all."
